Title: Jack the Ripper
Text: This is where the Ripper's first victim was found.

Title: Battle of Cable Street
Text: The Battle of Cable Street was a series of clashes that took place at several locations in the inner East End of London, most notably Cable Street, on Sunday 4 October 1936. It was a clash between the Metropolitan Police, sent to protect a march by members of the British Union of Fascists led by Oswald Mosley, and various de jure and de facto anti-fascist demonstrators, including local trade unionists, communists, anarchists, British Jews, supported in particular by Irish workers, and socialist groups. The anti-fascist counter-demonstration included both organised and unaffiliated participants.

Title: Great Fire of London
Text: The Great Fire of London was arguably the greatest tragedy of its time. Remarkably just six people were officially recorded to have lost their lives, but the Great Fire rendered almost 85% of London's population homeless. The fire started at a baker's shop on Pudding Lane and burned for almost five days, destroying over 13,000 tightly packed wooden houses, 87 churches and the iconic landmark, St Paul's Cathedral.

Title: London Mithraeum
Text: The Mithraeum lies below Bloomberg's European headquarters. This Roman Temple to the god Mithras was built in c. 240 AD, on the banks of the River Wallbrook, one of London's 'lost' rivers.

Title: Highgate Cemetery
Text: Highgate Cemetery is well known for being the resting place of Karl Marx, one of the most influential political thinkers of the 20th Century. It is also the resting place of George Eliot and George Michael, among many other familiar names from history.

Title: James Fillans
Text: Residence of sculptor James Fillans

Title: Special Operations Executive
Text: During World War II the Special Operations Executive (SOE) was based at 64 Baker Street, hence its nickname, the Baker Street Irregulars.

Title: Baker Street robbery
Text: The Baker Street robbery was the burglary of safety deposit boxes at the Baker Street branch of Lloyds Bank in London, on the night of 11 September 1971. A gang tunnelled 40 feet (12 m) from a rented shop two doors away to come up through the floor of the vault. The value of the property stolen is unknown, but is likely to have been between £1.25 million and £3 million; only £231,000 was recovered by the police.

Title: The March of the Guards to Finchley
Text: The March of the Guards to Finchley, also known as The March to Finchley or The March of the Guards, is a 1750 oil-on-canvas painting by English artist William Hogarth, owned by and on display at the Foundling Museum. The painting is a depiction of a fictional mustering of troops on the Tottenham Court Road to march north to Finchley to defend the capital from the second Jacobite rebellion of 1745, which was part of a series of uprisings that had been occurring since the late 17th century and were aimed at returning the Stuart Dynasty to the throne after the Glorious Revolution of 1688.

Title: Fairyland shooting range
Text: During the period leading up to and during the First World War, an amusement arcade that contained a miniature rifle-shooting range called Fairyland was at No. 92 Tottenham Court Road. In 1909, Madan Lal Dhingra practised shooting here prior to his assassination of Sir William Hutt Curzon Wyllie.

Title: Flannan Isles Lighthouse crew disappearance
Text: 'A dreadful accident has happened at the Flannans. The three keepers, Ducat, Marshall and the Occasional have disappeared from the Island... The clocks were stopped and other signs indicated that the accident must have happened about a week ago. Poor fellows they must have been blown over the cliffs or drowned trying to secure a crane.' - Telegram of Captain Harvie to the Northern Lighthouse Board 26.12.1900

Title: Landing site of Rudolf Hess
Text: Shortly before midnight on 10 May 1941, Hess landed at Floors Farm, by Waterfoot, south of Glasgow, where he was discovered still struggling with his parachute by local ploughman David McLean.

Title: Tottenham Court Road beer flood
Text: When a brewery exploded on Tottenham Court Road in 1814 the streets filled with beer. Up to 323,000 gallons killed 8 people living in the slums behind the site.

Title: Proposed death pyramid
Text: The Metropolitan Sepulchre was a massive pyramidal necropolis proposed for construction in Primrose Hill in London in the 19th century as a way of addressing the shortage of burial space in the London area.

Title: Tynwald
Text: Tynwald claims to be over 1,000 years old, and thus the 'oldest continuous parliament' in the world.

Title: The Theft of the Irish Crown Jewels
Text: In 1907, the Irish Crown Jewels, consisting of a diamond star and badge, were stolen from Dublin Castle. The theft remains a mystery, and the jewels were never recovered. It's one of the most famous unsolved mysteries in Irish history.

Title: The Haunting of Malahide Castle
Text: Malahide Castle, dating back to the 12th century, is rumored to be haunted by the ghost of a former owner, Miles Corbet. He was executed for his role in the English Civil War, and his spirit is said to roam the castle's halls to this day.

Title: The Phoenix Park Murders
Text: In 1882, Lord Frederick Cavendish and Thomas Henry Burke, two senior British officials, were brutally assassinated in Dublin's Phoenix Park. The murders were carried out by members of the Irish National Invincibles, a radical nationalist group, and had significant political consequences.

Title: The Hellfire Club on Montpelier Hill
Text: Montpelier Hill is home to the ruins of the infamous Hellfire Club, a secret society known for its debauchery and occult practices in the 18th century. The site is associated with eerie legends and stories of paranormal activity.

Title: The Battle of Dublin
Text: During the Easter Rising of 1916, Dublin saw intense fighting as Irish republicans attempted to gain independence from British rule. The city center was heavily damaged during the conflict, leaving a lasting mark on Dublin's history.

Title: Peterloo Massacre
Text: The Peterloo Massacre occurred on August 16, 1819, at St. Peter's Field in Manchester. A peaceful gathering of around 60,000 people who were advocating for parliamentary reform turned into a violent clash with the authorities. The cavalry charged into the crowd, resulting in 15 deaths and hundreds of injuries. This event played a significant role in the movement for democratic reforms in the United Kingdom.

Title: The Manchester Martyrs
Text: In 1867, three Irish nationalists, William Philip Allen, Michael Larkin, and Michael O'Brien, were executed in Manchester for their involvement in an attempt to rescue two imprisoned comrades. The Manchester Martyrs' execution led to widespread sympathy and support for the Irish nationalist cause, and their story remains an important part of Irish history.

Title: The Cotton Famine
Text: During the American Civil War in the 1860s, Manchester's textile mills faced a severe cotton shortage due to the disruption of cotton imports. This period, known as the 'Cotton Famine,' caused widespread unemployment and suffering. The city rallied together to provide relief efforts, demonstrating resilience in the face of economic hardship.

Title: The Halle Orchestra's First Concert
Text: On January 30, 1858, the Halle Orchestra, one of the UK's leading orchestras, held its first public concert at the Free Trade Hall in Manchester. This event marked the beginning of a long and prestigious history for the orchestra, contributing to Manchester's vibrant cultural scene.

Title: The Manchester Guardian's Origins
Text: The Manchester Guardian, now known as The Guardian, was founded in 1821 in Manchester by John Edward Taylor. It was established to support the liberal political views of the time. Over the years, it evolved into one of the UK's most influential newspapers, known for its progressive journalism and commitment to social justice.

Title: Cardiff Castle Roman Wall
Text: The Roman wall that can still be seen at Cardiff Castle dates back to the 3rd century AD. This ancient structure reminds us of the city's Roman history, with the fort of Cardiff guarding the eastern approaches to the Roman province of Britannia.

Title: Marquess of Bute's Legacy
Text: The Marquess of Bute, one of the wealthiest men of his time, funded the restoration of Cardiff Castle in the 19th century. His vision for the castle blended various architectural styles, resulting in a unique and picturesque landmark that stands as a testament to his influence on the city.

Title: The Cardiff Giant
Text: The Cardiff Giant was a famous hoax in the 19th century. A massive stone figure resembling a petrified man was 'discovered' in Cardiff, New York, and later displayed in Cardiff, Wales. It turned out to be a forgery, but the story of this 'giant' continues to captivate history enthusiasts.

Title: Welsh Bards and the Eisteddfod
Text: Cardiff has a rich tradition of hosting the National Eisteddfod of Wales, a festival of Welsh culture and the arts. The Eisteddfod has celebrated Welsh literature, music, and poetry since its inception in the 12th century. It's a unique showcase of the nation's cultural heritage.

Title: The Necropolis
Text: Glasgow Necropolis, a Victorian cemetery, is the final resting place of over 50,000 people, including notable figures like Charles Rennie Mackintosh and John Knox.

Title: The Battle of George Square
Text: In 1919, the Battle of George Square saw a mass protest in Glasgow for better working conditions turn violent, with troops being deployed to quell the unrest.

Title: Glasgow Ice Cream Wars
Text: The infamous Glasgow Ice Cream Wars in the 1980s involved territorial disputes between ice cream van operators and led to violent conflicts and even murder.

Title: The World's First International Football Match
Text: Glasgow is the historic site where the world's first international football match took place in 1872 between Scotland and England, ending in a 0-0 draw.

Title: The Gorbals Vampire
Text: In the 1950s, rumors of a vampire in the Gorbals district led to children hunting for the mythical creature, creating a local legend.

Title: The Burke and Hare Murders
Text: In the early 19th century, Irishmen William Burke and William Hare infamously murdered vulnerable individuals in Edinburgh to sell their bodies to medical schools. Their gruesome actions came to be known as the Burke and Hare Murders, shedding light on the dark trade of supplying cadavers for anatomical research and leading to changes in the law surrounding corpse disposal.

Title: The Darien Scheme
Text: The Darien Scheme was a failed 17th-century Scottish colonization project in Panama. Thousands of Scots invested their savings in the hope of creating a prosperous colony. Due to disease, famine, and attacks, the project ended in disaster, severely impacting the Scottish economy and contributing to the 1707 Act of Union with England.

Title: The Great Fire of Edinburgh
Text: In 1824, the Great Fire of Edinburgh ravaged the Old Town, destroying over 400 buildings. The fire started in the High Street and quickly spread, leaving thousands homeless. The event led to improved city planning and the construction of the elegant buildings in the New Town that we see today.

Title: Greyfriars Bobby
Text: Greyfriars Bobby was a Skye Terrier who became famous in the 19th century for faithfully guarding his owner's grave in Greyfriars Kirkyard for 14 years after the owner's death. Bobby's loyalty captured the hearts of many, and a statue in his honor now stands in Edinburgh.

Title: The Stone of Destiny
Text: The Stone of Destiny, also known as the Stone of Scone, was kept in Edinburgh Castle for centuries and used in the coronation of Scottish and later English monarchs. It was stolen by Scottish nationalists in 1950 but later recovered. The Stone now resides in Scotland during peacetime and in Westminster Abbey for English coronations.

Title: The Lady of the Lake
Text: According to Welsh folklore, the 'Lady of the Lake' is said to have appeared at Llyn y Fan Fach in the Brecon Beacons. She is associated with magical tales of granting a shepherd named Gwyn the knowledge of herbal medicine and the promise that his descendants would possess special healing powers.

Title: The Great Welsh Revolt
Text: The Great Welsh Revolt of 1839, also known as the Newport Rising, saw thousands of Chartists, demanding political reform, marching on Newport. The confrontation with authorities led to violence, and several Chartists lost their lives. This event played a significant role in the history of the Chartist movement in the UK.

Title: The Conwy Castle Ghost
Text: Conwy Castle, a medieval fortress in North Wales, is believed to be haunted by a ghostly apparition of a woman in white. Local legend suggests that she is the spirit of a woman who was falsely accused of poisoning her husband and then executed. Her ghostly presence is said to wander the castle's walls and towers.

Title: The Aberfan Disaster
Text: The Aberfan Disaster occurred in 1966 when a coal mining waste tip collapsed, engulfing a primary school in the village of Aberfan, South Wales. Tragically, 116 children and 28 adults lost their lives in the disaster. The event led to significant changes in mining regulations and the management of coal waste in the UK.

Title: The Witches of Belvoir
Text: In the early 17th century, the witch hunts reached the rural town of Belvoir. Local women, including Joan Flower and her daughters, were accused of witchcraft and put on trial. This event led to the last mass witchcraft trial in England, resulting in the execution of several accused witches.

Title: The Great Fire of Nantwich
Text: In 1583, the town of Nantwich in Cheshire suffered a devastating fire. The fire destroyed most of the town's buildings, and the event is still remembered today through a historic and picturesque town center that was rebuilt in the aftermath.

Title: The Devil's Footprints
Text: In 1855, strange hoof-like footprints appeared in the snow across rural Devon. These 'Devil's Footprints' covered over 100 miles, baffling residents. The mysterious tracks remain a topic of folklore and legend in the region.

Title: The Wandering Jew of Hampstead
Text: In the 19th century, a man named Louis Cyphern was known as the 'Wandering Jew of Hampstead.' He claimed to be the biblical figure doomed to wander the earth. His presence in rural Hampstead drew curious onlookers and sparked discussions about faith and superstition.

Title: The Civil War Siege of Basing House
Text: During the English Civil War, Basing House, located in rural Hampshire, became a Royalist stronghold. It endured multiple sieges, with the final one in 1645 leading to its destruction. The ruins of Basing House serve as a reminder of this significant conflict.

Title: The Pirate Queen of Clew Bay
Text: Grace O'Malley, known as the Pirate Queen, ruled the seas off Clew Bay in the 16th century. She commanded a fleet of ships and was a fearless warrior, fighting against the English Crown's encroachment on her territory. Grace's audacity and cunning made her a legend in Irish history.

Title: The Puck Fair
Text: The Puck Fair, an ancient festival held in Killorglin, County Kerry, dates back to 1613. It involves crowning a wild mountain goat as 'King Puck' and celebrating with parades, music, and merriment. The festival is a unique blend of Irish folklore and rural traditions.

Title: The Wandering Rocks
Text: The 'Wandering Rocks' in County Sligo are a group of boulders with a mysterious history. According to local legend, these rocks move on their own during certain lunar phases. While it's likely a natural phenomenon, the rocks have captured the imagination of many for centuries.

Title: The Flight of the Earls
Text: In 1607, the Flight of the Earls saw Irish nobility, including Hugh O'Neill and Rory O'Donnell, leave their homeland for continental Europe to escape English oppression. This event marked the end of the Gaelic lordship system in Ireland and had a significant impact on Irish history.
